content.description: Climbs the north west arete. Starts in a big nice 3-finger pocket then up on pebbles and sloper. Have fun topping out if you are by yourself.
content.location:
This is to the right of

Northwest Overhang

on the NW corner of the Pebble Wall boulder.

content.description: Start on the Southeast face with your right hand in a pod under the lip and your left in a large dish, scumming your left heel.  Go for the obvious pebble and continue to traverse right out to the corner for an obvious mantle topout. Note, I got the name and info from Chip Phillips' Guide but lowered the grade to a 5 instead of a 6. A 6 couldn't be justified with Eric Varney so close.
content.location: This is on the Pebble Boulder, it is the face nearest to Red Wall.

content.description:
Start with your left hand in a dish and your right hand on an incut hold. Figure our how to get you're legs up, reach for a good high pebble, and top out.

Beta Video
content.location: This is right past where you have to squeeze between two boulders as you walk around towards The Red Wall.

content.description:
Start as for

Strege Problem

, but go straight up. Starting on the dish with your left hand and the bad under... thing, with your right, move up to the big pebble, and then work your way up to an easy topout. The standstart goes at V1.
content.location:
This is on the southeast face of the boulder. It is just left of the Northeast Mantle. It starts like the

Strege Problem

.

content.description:
First off, I'm not sure this is the correct name for this problem, so if anyone knows what it is or who did the FA, feel free to submit a change or let me know and I will.

This problem is on the Northeast corner of the Pebble Boulder above an exposed tree root. One can identify it by a seam with two handholds that angles down and left; these are your starting handholds. To start, put your hands on the handholds and get your feet up; however, you like it-some use a heel hook, other just use a toe under the 'hang. From here, blast up to the sloping ledge above, and then grunt your way up and over the bulge, mantel-ing as you go, utilizing if need be the next sloping ledge above. I personally like to put my left foot on the starting handholds and then rock onto it for the mantel.

This is a classic scrape your legs and stomach problem and a must do for Flagstaff firsters.

I give it two stars, because no one else will, and because it's such a battle.
content.protection: There's a big root and ledge below this problem, and you have to hang upside down almost to start it, so it can hurt to fall unless you position your pad appropriately.

content.description: Climb on the north side of the Pebble Wall boulder. Hard moves going from the middle of the overhang gain the pebble on top of the lip.
content.location: This is on the North side of Pebble Wall boulder. It climbs the middle of the face. It is right of the walk up trail.

content.description: Left of the crystal mantle is a line of small pebbles and crystals that lead you directly up the south face of the Pebble Wall.  Kind of tall and thin at the top.

This is the first problem you see when you arrive at the Pebble Boulder from the trail. It is just before the slot between the main boulder and a small, head height boulder to the right (east). You can identify it by the giant, diving board pebble sticking out of the wall and the low flake sit start.

Sit start on the flake, go up to the crystal, and figure a way to use it and the face holds above and right of it to get your feet up so you can reach the lip.  I've seen it done a million and one ways, but the name says what comes easiest for most people: mantel the crystal if ya can.
content.protection: The landing is big and flat. A pad is all you need, and the topout is fairly straightforward.
